explanations: This is the past casual form of a verb
It either ends in た or だ and is formed by changing the て or で of the て-form to た or だ respectively

topic: Verb た-form ことが あります
explanations: This expression is used to say that one has experienced something before, without saying when it occured
[Note] Since the experience was in the past, make sure to use the past tense of the verb
examples: 1) うまに 乗[の]った ことが あります。
2) 去年[きょねん] 北海道[ほっかいどう]で 馬[うま]に のりました。
2) I rode a horse last yaear in Hokkaido

topic: Verb1 た-formり，... Verb2 た-formり します
explanations: Previously, we used the particle や when citing two or more nouns as examples from a longer list
We use り appended to the end of the verb to do the same for verbs
[Note] The tense is only shown at the end of the sentence
examples: 1) 日曜日[にちようび]は テニスを したり，映画[えいが]を 見[み]たり します。
1) On Sundays, I play tennis, watch a film, and so on
2) 日曜日[にちようび]は テニスを したり，映画[えいが]を 見[み]たり しました。
2) Last Sunday, I played tennis, watched a film, and did other stuff

explanations: This expression is used to express two or more actions that occur one after another
examples: 1) 日曜日[にちようび]は テニスを して，映画[えいが]を 見[み]た。
1) On Sunday, I played tennis and then watched a film

explanations: なります indicates a change of state
For い-adjs, remove the trailing い and append く before なります
examples: 1) 寒い[さむい] → 寒く なります

explanations: なります indicates a change of state
For な-adjs, remove the trailing な and append に before なります
examples: 1) 元気[げんき](な) → 元気[げんき]に なります

explanations: なります indicates a change of state
For Nouns, just append に before なります
examples: 1) 25歳[さい] → 25歳[さい]に なります
